title: Shape Sequences
subtitle: Find what comes next in a pattern of shapes

sections.heading: What is this question type?
sections.body:
In a Shape Sequence question, you are shown a row of shapes that change step by step following a hidden rule. Your job is to work out what the rule is and choose the shape that comes next.

The shapes might change in many ways: they could rotate, get bigger or smaller, change their shading, or swap position. Sometimes two or more things change at once, so you need to look carefully at every detail.

These questions test your ability to spot patterns - a skill that is very important in the 11+ GL Assessment Non-Verbal Reasoning paper.

visual.code:
flowchart LR
  A[Shape 1] --> B[Shape 2]
  B --> C[Shape 3]
  C --> D[Shape 4]
  D --> E["? What next"]
  style E fill:#f96,stroke:#333

steps.label: Spot the changes
steps.detail: Compare each shape to the one before it. Ask yourself: what changed? Look at shape type, size, shading, rotation, position, and number of sides.

steps.label: Name the rule
steps.detail: Describe the pattern in words, for example: 'the shape rotates 90 degrees clockwise each time' or 'the shading increases by one quarter each step'.

steps.label: Check it holds
steps.detail: Make sure your rule works for every step in the sequence, not just the first two shapes.

steps.label: Predict and match
steps.detail: Apply your rule to predict what the next shape should look like, then find the matching answer option.

question.text:
Look at how the shapes change. Which shape comes next in the sequence?

Imagine: Square(white) -> Square(quarter shaded) -> Square(half shaded) -> Square(three-quarters shaded) -> ?

walkthrough.text: Look at the shape: it stays a square throughout, so the shape itself does not change.
Look at the shading: white (0%), quarter (25%), half (50%), three-quarters (75%). The shading increases by 25% each time.
Applying the rule: 75% + 25% = 100%. The next shape should be a fully shaded square.

items.trap: Only noticing one change when there are two
items.fix: Always check ALL properties: shape, size, shading, rotation, position, and number of elements. Many hard questions have two rules working at the same time.

items.trap: Confusing rotation direction
items.fix: Use your finger to trace the rotation. Clockwise goes the same way as clock hands. Anticlockwise goes the opposite way.

items.trap: Assuming the pattern repeats after the last shape shown
items.fix: The pattern continues forward. If shading goes 0%, 25%, 50%, 75%, the next is 100%, not back to 0% (unless the question shows a repeating cycle).

title: Odd One Out
subtitle: Spot the shape that does not belong with the others

sections.heading: What is this question type?
sections.body:
In an Odd One Out question, you are shown five shapes. Four of them share something in common - they follow the same rule or have a shared feature. One shape is different and does not fit the pattern. You must find that odd shape.

The shared feature could be anything: the number of sides, the type of shading, the direction of rotation, the number of internal lines, or even a combination of features. The trick is to find the rule that connects exactly four shapes and leaves one out.

This question type appears regularly on GL Assessment papers and tests your ability to classify and group shapes by their properties.

visual.code:
flowchart TD
  Q["Five shapes shown"] --> G["4 shapes share a feature"]
  Q --> O["1 shape is DIFFERENT"]
  G --> R["Find the shared rule"]
  O --> A["That is your answer"]
  style O fill:#f96,stroke:#333
  style A fill:#f96,stroke:#333

steps.label: List properties
steps.detail: For each shape, note its properties: number of sides, shading (white, grey, black), size (small, medium, large), orientation, symmetry, and any internal details like lines or dots.

steps.label: Look for a group of four
steps.detail: Try to find a property that exactly four shapes share. For example, four shapes might all have curved edges while one has straight edges.

steps.label: Test your rule
steps.detail: Check that your rule includes exactly four shapes and excludes exactly one. If it excludes two or more, your rule is too strict - try a different property.

steps.label: Pick the odd one
steps.detail: The shape that does not fit your rule is the answer.

question.text:
Which shape is the odd one out?

Imagine five shapes:
A: Triangle with 1 dot inside
B: Square with 1 dot inside
C: Pentagon with 1 dot inside
D: Hexagon with 2 dots inside
E: Circle with 1 dot inside

walkthrough.text: List properties: All shapes are different types (triangle, square, pentagon, hexagon, circle). Look at the dots inside each shape.
A, B, C, and E each have exactly 1 dot inside. Shape D has 2 dots inside.
The rule connecting four shapes is: 'has exactly 1 dot inside'. Shape D breaks this rule because it has 2 dots.

items.trap: Picking the shape that looks most different visually
items.fix: Do not just go by first impressions. A circle might look different from squares and triangles, but the odd one out could be based on shading, not shape type.

items.trap: Finding a rule that excludes two shapes
items.fix: Your rule must leave exactly one shape out. If two shapes do not fit, your rule is wrong - keep looking for a different property.

items.trap: Ignoring small details like dots, lines, or arrows inside shapes
items.fix: Always look inside the shapes as well as at their outlines. Small details like internal lines, dots, or arrows are often the key feature.

title: Shape Analogies
subtitle: Shape A is to Shape B as Shape C is to ...?

sections.heading: What is this question type?
sections.body:
In a Shape Analogy question, you are given a pair of shapes (A and B) that are related by a rule. Then you are given a third shape (C) and must find the shape (from the answer options) that relates to C in the same way that B relates to A.

Think of it like this: 'Shape A is to Shape B as Shape C is to ?'. You need to work out what happened to turn A into B, and then apply that same change to C.

The change could involve rotation, reflection, shading, adding or removing elements, changing size, or swapping colours. This question type tests your ability to identify and transfer rules from one pair to another.

visual.code:
flowchart LR
  A["Shape A"] -->|"rule"| B["Shape B"]
  C["Shape C"] -->|"same rule"| D["? Answer"]
  style D fill:#f96,stroke:#333

steps.label: Study the first pair
steps.detail: Look closely at Shape A and Shape B. Ask: what changed? Did it rotate, flip, change shading, gain or lose elements, grow or shrink?

steps.label: Name the rule clearly
steps.detail: Describe the change in words: 'the shape rotates 90 degrees clockwise and the shading swaps from white to black'. Be as precise as you can.

steps.label: Apply the rule to Shape C
steps.detail: Take Shape C and apply exactly the same changes you found in step 2. Picture what the result should look like.

steps.label: Match your prediction
steps.detail: Find the answer option that matches your predicted result.

question.text:
Shape A is to Shape B as Shape C is to ?

Imagine:
A: Large white circle
B: Small black circle
C: Large white square

What should replace the question mark?

walkthrough.text: Compare A to B: A is a large white circle. B is a small black circle. Two things changed: size went from large to small, and shading went from white to black.
The rule is: make it smaller AND change the shading from white to black. The shape type stays the same (circle stays as circle).
Apply the rule to C (large white square): make it smaller and change white to black. The answer should be a small black square.

items.trap: Only applying part of the rule
items.fix: If two changes happen between A and B (for example size AND shading), make sure you apply both changes to C, not just one.

items.trap: Applying the rule to the wrong shape
items.fix: You apply the rule to Shape C, not to Shape B. The answer relates to C, not to B.

items.trap: Confusing what stays the same with what changes
items.fix: If the shape type does not change between A and B (both are circles), then the shape type should not change between C and the answer either (square stays as square).

title: Shape Matrices
subtitle: Complete a grid of shapes by finding the missing piece

sections.heading: What is this question type?
sections.body:
In a Shape Matrix question, you see a grid (usually 3x3 or 2x2) of shapes with one box empty. The shapes in each row follow a rule, and the shapes in each column follow a rule too. You must find the shape that correctly fills the empty box by satisfying both the row rule and the column rule at the same time.

Think of it like a puzzle where the rows and columns each tell you part of the answer. You need to combine those clues to find the one shape that fits perfectly.

These are among the trickiest NVR questions because you must think about patterns in two directions at once.

visual.code:
flowchart TD
  subgraph Grid
    direction LR
    R1["Row 1: shape shape shape"]
    R2["Row 2: shape shape shape"]
    R3["Row 3: shape shape ?"]
  end
  R1 -->|"Row rule"| P1["Pattern across"]
  R3 -->|"Column rule"| P2["Pattern down"]
  P1 --> A["Answer must fit BOTH"]
  P2 --> A
  style R3 fill:#f96,stroke:#333
  style A fill:#6f9,stroke:#333

steps.label: Read the rows
steps.detail: Look across each row. What stays the same? What changes? For example, the shape might stay the same across a row but the shading changes.

steps.label: Read the columns
steps.detail: Now look down each column. What pattern do you see? Perhaps the size increases going down, or the number of sides changes.

steps.label: Combine the clues
steps.detail: The missing shape must satisfy both the row rule and the column rule. Use the row to narrow down some properties, then use the column to narrow down the rest.

steps.label: Pick the answer
steps.detail: Find the option that matches all the properties you have worked out.

question.text:
Complete the 3x3 grid. The missing shape is in the bottom-right corner.

Imagine:
Row 1: Circle(small) | Circle(medium) | Circle(large)
Row 2: Square(small) | Square(medium) | Square(large)
Row 3: Triangle(small) | Triangle(medium) | ?

What fills the gap?

walkthrough.text: Row rule: In each row, the shape type stays the same and the size increases from small to medium to large. Row 3 has triangles, so the missing shape is a triangle, and it should be large.
Column rule: In each column, the size stays the same but the shape type changes: circle, square, triangle. Column 3 has circle(large), square(large), so the missing shape should be triangle(large).
Both rules agree: the answer is a large triangle.

items.trap: Only checking rows and forgetting columns
items.fix: Always check both directions. The answer must work for its row AND its column.

items.trap: Getting confused by grids with three changing properties
items.fix: Break it down: first work out the shape, then the size, then the shading. Handle one property at a time.

items.trap: Rushing and picking the first option that partly matches
items.fix: Check every property of your chosen answer against both the row and column rules before committing.

sections.heading: What is this question type?
sections.body:
In a Rotation question, you are given a shape and must identify which of the answer options shows the same shape rotated (turned) to a different angle. The shape is not flipped or reflected - it is only turned around its centre point.

Rotation means spinning the shape like turning a steering wheel. Clockwise rotation goes in the same direction as clock hands (to the right). Anticlockwise rotation goes in the opposite direction (to the left).

Common rotation amounts are 90 degrees (a quarter turn), 180 degrees (a half turn), and 270 degrees (a three-quarter turn). The shape itself does not change - only its orientation changes.

visual.code:
flowchart LR
  O["Original shape"] -->|"90 clockwise"| R1["Quarter turn"]
  O -->|"180"| R2["Half turn"]
  O -->|"270 clockwise"| R3["Three-quarter turn"]
  O -->|"360"| R4["Back to start"]
  style O fill:#fbb,stroke:#333

steps.label: Find a key feature
steps.detail: Pick a distinctive part of the shape - a notch, a dot, a pointed corner, or an asymmetric detail. This will be your 'anchor' to track the rotation.

steps.label: Track the feature
steps.detail: Imagine (or use your finger to trace) where that key feature would move if the shape were rotated. For 90 degrees clockwise, something pointing up would move to point right.

steps.label: Check it is not a reflection
steps.detail: A rotated shape keeps everything in the same relative order. If details appear 'flipped' or in mirror order, it is a reflection, not a rotation. Eliminate those options.

steps.label: Confirm your answer
steps.detail: Check that ALL parts of the shape match the rotated version, not just your anchor feature.

question.text:
Which option shows this shape rotated 90 degrees clockwise?

Imagine the original: An L-shape pointing up and to the right (like the letter L but with the foot going right).

Options:
A: L-shape with foot pointing down (rotated 90 clockwise)
B: L-shape with foot pointing left (rotated 180)
C: Backwards L-shape with foot pointing right (reflected)
D: L-shape with foot pointing up (rotated 270 clockwise)
E: Same as original (not rotated)

walkthrough.text: The original L-shape has its long arm going up and its short foot going to the right. Our key feature is the foot direction.
When we rotate 90 degrees clockwise: up becomes right, right becomes down. So the long arm should now point to the right and the foot should point down. This matches option A.
Option C is a trap - it looks similar but it is a mirror image (reflected), not a rotation. Notice the foot goes the wrong way relative to the arm.

items.trap: Mixing up rotation and reflection
items.fix: A rotation is a turn. A reflection is a flip (mirror image). If the shape looks like it has been flipped over, it is reflected, not rotated. A quick check: trace the outline in one direction - a rotated shape keeps the same 'handedness' while a reflected one reverses it.

items.trap: Getting clockwise and anticlockwise confused
items.fix: Clockwise is the direction clock hands move: top goes right, right goes down, down goes left, left goes up. Anticlockwise is the reverse.

items.trap: Not checking all details after finding the rotation
items.fix: Sometimes two options have the same outline rotation but differ in internal details (dots, lines, shading). Always verify every detail.

title: Reflection
subtitle: Identify reflected or mirror versions of shapes

sections.heading: What is this question type?
sections.body:
In a Reflection question, you must identify which answer option shows the mirror image of a given shape. A reflection is what you would see if you placed a mirror along a line next to the shape.

There are two main types of reflection:

  • Horizontal reflection - the mirror line is vertical (up-down), so the shape flips left to right, like looking in a bathroom mirror.
  • Vertical reflection - the mirror line is horizontal (left-right), so the shape flips top to bottom, like looking at a reflection in a pond.

When a shape is reflected, everything swaps sides. If a dot is on the left in the original, it appears on the right in the reflection. The shape is NOT rotated - it is flipped.

visual.code:
flowchart LR
  O["Original"] -->|"Vertical mirror line"| R1["Left-Right flip"]
  O -->|"Horizontal mirror line"| R2["Top-Bottom flip"]
  subgraph Key Idea
    K["Everything swaps sides across the mirror line"]
  end
  style O fill:#f9f,stroke:#333
  style K fill:#ff9,stroke:#333

steps.label: Find the mirror line
steps.detail: The question may tell you where the mirror line is (to the right, below, etc.) or you may need to work it out. This tells you which direction the shape flips.

steps.label: Pick an asymmetric detail
steps.detail: Find a feature that is NOT in the centre of the shape - a dot on one side, a notch on one corner, an arrow pointing one direction. This feature must swap sides in the reflection.

steps.label: Flip, do not rotate
steps.detail: Imagine pressing the shape against the mirror line and seeing its print on the other side. Left becomes right (or top becomes bottom). Do NOT turn the shape - that would be rotation.

steps.label: Match the reflection
steps.detail: Find the option where your key detail has swapped sides correctly and all other properties remain unchanged.

question.text:
Which option shows the reflection of this shape in a vertical mirror line (placed to the right)?

Imagine the original: A right-pointing arrow with a black dot at its top-left corner.

Options:
A: Left-pointing arrow with black dot at top-right corner
B: Left-pointing arrow with black dot at top-left corner
C: Right-pointing arrow with black dot at bottom-left corner
D: Down-pointing arrow with black dot at top-left corner
E: Left-pointing arrow with black dot at bottom-right corner

walkthrough.text: The mirror line is vertical (to the right), so we flip left and right. The arrow should now point left instead of right.
The black dot is at the top-left. When we reflect left-right, left becomes right and right becomes left. But top stays top. So the dot should move to the top-right corner.
Option A has a left-pointing arrow with the dot at the top-right corner. This matches our reflection perfectly.

items.trap: Rotating instead of reflecting
items.fix: Rotation turns the whole shape around a point. Reflection flips it across a line. A reflected shape has its 'handedness' reversed - like your left hand reflected becomes a right hand.

items.trap: Reflecting across the wrong line
items.fix: Read the question carefully. A vertical mirror line (up-down line) flips left and right. A horizontal mirror line (left-right line) flips top and bottom. Do not mix them up.

items.trap: Forgetting to flip internal details
items.fix: Everything flips in a reflection, including dots, lines, shading patterns, and arrows inside the shape. If the original has a line in the top-left, the reflection has it in the top-right (for a vertical mirror line).

title: 3D Spatial Reasoning
subtitle: Visualise 3D shapes, nets of cubes, and folding

sections.heading: What is this question type?
sections.body:
3D Spatial Reasoning questions test your ability to think in three dimensions. The most common type shows you a net (a flat shape that folds up into a 3D shape) and asks which 3D shape it would make, or the other way around.

A net is what you get if you cut along the edges of a box and unfold it flat. For example, a cube net has 6 squares arranged so they can fold into a cube.

Other questions might ask you to:

  • Identify which cube can be made from a given net
  • Work out which faces are opposite each other when the net is folded
  • Visualise what a shape looks like from a different viewpoint (top, side, front)

The key skill is being able to imagine folding and unfolding shapes in your head.

visual.code:
flowchart TD
  N["Flat Net"] -->|"Fold up"| C["3D Cube"]
  C -->|"Unfold"| N
  subgraph Think About
    F1["Which faces touch?"]
    F2["Which faces are opposite?"]
    F3["Which way do patterns face?"]
  end
  C --> F1
  C --> F2
  C --> F3
  style N fill:#daf,stroke:#333
  style C fill:#daf,stroke:#333

steps.label: Identify the base face
steps.detail: Pick one square in the net as the 'base' (bottom of the cube). This gives you a starting point to work out where the other faces end up.

steps.label: Fold in your mind
steps.detail: Mentally fold each face up from the base, one at a time. Track which face becomes the top, front, back, left, right. Use your fingers to mime the folding if it helps.

steps.label: Check opposites
steps.detail: In a cube net, opposite faces can never share an edge. If two squares share an edge in the net, they are adjacent faces, not opposite. Opposite faces are always separated by one square.

steps.label: Match patterns and orientation
steps.detail: If the faces have patterns (dots, stripes, letters), track how they rotate when folded. A pattern facing up in the net might face sideways on the cube.

question.text:
A cube net is shown with 6 squares in a cross shape (+). The centre square has a STAR. The square above the centre has a CIRCLE. The square below has a TRIANGLE. The square to the left has STRIPES. The square to the right has DOTS. The bottom of the cross (below the triangle) has a HEART.

If the STAR face is the base (bottom of the cube), which pattern is on the top face?

walkthrough.text: Place the STAR as the base (bottom). The squares directly connected to the centre (CIRCLE above, TRIANGLE below, STRIPES left, DOTS right) fold up to become the four side faces.
The HEART is below the TRIANGLE in the net. When we fold the TRIANGLE up to become the front face, the HEART continues folding and ends up on top.
So the top face (opposite the STAR base) is the HEART. Notice that STAR and HEART do not share an edge in the net - they are separated by the TRIANGLE, confirming they are opposite faces.

items.trap: Thinking adjacent faces in the net are opposite on the cube
items.fix: If two squares share an edge in the net, they will be side-by-side (adjacent) on the cube, NOT opposite. Opposite faces are always separated by at least one square in the net.

items.trap: Forgetting that patterns rotate when faces fold
items.fix: When a face folds up, any pattern on it may change orientation. An arrow pointing right on the flat net might point up when that face is folded to become a side. Track the direction carefully.

items.trap: Not recognising valid cube nets
items.fix: There are exactly 11 different nets that fold into a cube. A quick rule: a valid net has exactly 6 squares, no overlapping when folded, and no more than 4 squares in a row.

title: Shape Codes
subtitle: Crack the code that describes each shape

sections.heading: What is this question type?
sections.body:
In a Shape Codes question, you are shown several shapes, each with a two-letter or three-letter code. Each letter in the code represents one property of the shape - for example, one letter might stand for the shape type, another for the shading, and another for the size.

Your job is to work out what each letter means by comparing the codes and shapes. Then you use your knowledge to find the correct code for a new shape, or to find which shape matches a given code.

This is like cracking a secret code. You compare shapes that share a letter to find out what that letter represents.

visual.code:
flowchart TD
  subgraph Given
    S1["Shape 1 = AX"]
    S2["Shape 2 = BX"]
    S3["Shape 3 = AY"]
  end
  S1 --> C1["Compare S1 and S2: same X, different A/B"]
  S1 --> C2["Compare S1 and S3: same A, different X/Y"]
  C1 --> D1["X = shared property"]
  C2 --> D2["A = shared property"]
  D1 --> ANS["Crack the code!"]
  D2 --> ANS
  style ANS fill:#99f,stroke:#333

steps.label: List properties of each shape
steps.detail: Write down the properties of each shape: type (circle, square, etc.), shading (white, grey, black), size (small, large), and any extras (number of sides, dots, lines).

steps.label: Compare shapes with shared code letters
steps.detail: Find two shapes that share a code letter. What property do they also share? That letter stands for that property. For example, if shapes with code 'A_' are both circles, then A means circle.

steps.label: Confirm with different shapes
steps.detail: Check your theory with another pair. If shapes without 'A' are not circles, that confirms A = circle.

steps.label: Build the full code and answer
steps.detail: Once you know what each letter means, build the code for the new shape by looking at its properties.

question.text:
Each shape has a two-letter code. Work out what each letter means.

Shape 1: Large circle = AX
Shape 2: Large square = BX
Shape 3: Small circle = AY
Shape 4: Small triangle = CY

What is the code for a Large triangle?

walkthrough.text: Compare Shape 1 (AX, large circle) and Shape 2 (BX, large square). They share the letter X and are both large. They differ in A vs B and circle vs square. So the first letter is the shape type: A = circle, B = square. And X relates to being large.

Compare Shape 1 (AX, large circle) and Shape 3 (AY, small circle). They share the letter A and are both circles. They differ in X vs Y and large vs small. This confirms: A = circle, X = large, Y = small.
Look at Shape 4 (CY, small triangle). Y = small (which we already know), and this is a triangle, so C = triangle. For a large triangle: C (triangle) + X (large) = CX.

items.trap: Guessing what a letter means without comparing shapes
items.fix: Always compare two shapes that share a letter. The property they have in common is what the letter represents. Never guess based on a single shape.

items.trap: Mixing up which letter represents which property
items.fix: Write a clear key as you decode: 'First letter = shape type, Second letter = size'. Keep referring back to your key.

items.trap: Forgetting to check your code against all given shapes
items.fix: After you think you have cracked the code, verify it works for every shape shown. If it fails for even one shape, reconsider your theory.

title: Visual Reasoning
subtitle: General pattern recognition and visual problem solving

sections.heading: What is this question type?
sections.body:
Visual Reasoning is a broad category that covers various pattern recognition and visual problem-solving questions. These questions might not fit neatly into the other NVR categories but still test your ability to see patterns, relationships, and rules in shapes and figures.

You might be asked to:

  • Find which shape belongs to a group (classification)
  • Identify a shape that has been hidden or overlapped
  • Work out how shapes combine or overlap
  • Spot patterns in arrangements of shapes, lines, or dots
  • Determine which shape results from combining or subtracting other shapes

The key to all visual reasoning is to be systematic. Instead of guessing by 'feel', break the problem down and check each property one at a time.

visual.code:
mindmap
  root((Visual Reasoning))
    Classification
      Which group does this shape belong to?
    Overlap
      What do you see when shapes combine?
    Hidden shapes
      Which shape is hiding underneath?
    Combination
      What shape results from adding or subtracting?

steps.label: Understand the question type
steps.detail: Read the instructions carefully. Are you grouping shapes, combining shapes, or finding hidden shapes? Each type needs a slightly different approach.

steps.label: List all visible properties
steps.detail: For each shape or figure, note down: shape type, size, shading, number of internal elements, line styles (solid, dashed, thick, thin), symmetry, and orientation.

steps.label: Find the rule or relationship
steps.detail: Look for what connects the shapes. In classification questions, find the shared rule. In combination questions, work out how the shapes interact (overlap, subtract, combine).

steps.label: Eliminate wrong answers
steps.detail: If you cannot immediately see the right answer, use elimination. Check each option against your rule and cross out those that fail.

question.text:
Two groups of shapes are shown. Work out the rule for each group, then decide which group a new shape belongs to.

Group 1: Triangle(black), Square(black), Pentagon(black)
Group 2: Triangle(white), Square(white), Circle(white)

New shape: Hexagon(black)

Which group does the new shape belong to?

walkthrough.text: Look at Group 1: the shapes are all different (triangle, square, pentagon) but they are all black (fully shaded). The rule for Group 1 appears to be: 'the shape is black/shaded'.
Look at Group 2: the shapes are all different (triangle, square, circle) and they are all white (unshaded). The rule for Group 2 appears to be: 'the shape is white/unshaded'.
The new shape is a hexagon that is black. Since it is black, it matches the Group 1 rule. The shape type (hexagon) does not matter - only the shading determines the group.

items.trap: Overthinking when the rule is simple
items.fix: Start with the simplest possible rule (such as colour or number of sides) before looking for complex patterns. GL Assessment questions at this level usually have clear, single-feature rules.

items.trap: Being distracted by irrelevant features
items.fix: If shapes in a group differ in size but share the same shading, the rule is about shading, not size. Focus on what is CONSISTENT within a group.

items.trap: Not reading the question carefully
items.fix: Some questions ask 'which group', others ask 'which shape completes the set'. Make sure you answer what is actually being asked.
